reanalysis_method: Re-ingested all uploaded PDFs listed in repository root using the existing extraction-derived concept inventory from those PDFs.
Conservatively split content into six primary domains aligned to module boundaries and explicit section themes.
Mapped each atomic fact to one primary domain; optional secondary tags reserved for integrated questions.

domains.name: Identifying Child Abuse and Neglect
domains.why_this_domain_exists: Module content centers on definitions, indicators, risk/protective factors, and prohibited caregiver conduct used to identify concern patterns before reporting.
domains.confidence_note: Boundary overlaps with D2 when identification triggers mandatory reporting; primary mapping remains identification tasks.

policies: Physical, emotional, sexual abuse and neglect are distinct categories described in the source modules.
Risk factors are described across child, family, and environmental levels.
Staff should distinguish observed facts from assumptions.
definitions: Neglect includes failure to provide support, supervision, affection, attention, and normal living experiences.
Protective factors reduce likelihood of maltreatment and should be considered in context.
Unexplained recurring injuries and extreme behavior changes warrant concern escalation.
procedures_workflows: Indicators can be physical signs, behavioral changes, or interactional red flags that require objective documentation.
Observation of caregiver-child interactions can reveal escalating concern patterns.
Failure to act on credible indicators can place children at continued risk.
roles_responsibilities: Risk factors are described across child, family, and environmental levels.
Staff should distinguish observed facts from assumptions.
prohibited_actions_violations: Neglect includes failure to provide support, supervision, affection, attention, and normal living experiences.
Failure to act on credible indicators can place children at continued risk.
scenario_judgment_calls: Protective factors reduce likelihood of maltreatment and should be considered in context.
Staff should distinguish observed facts from assumptions.

subtopics.name: Abuse and neglect categories
atomic_facts: Physical, emotional, sexual abuse and neglect are distinct categories described in the source modules.
Neglect includes failure to provide support, supervision, affection, attention, and normal living experiences.
Indicators can be physical signs, behavioral changes, or interactional red flags that require objective documentation.

subtopics.name: Contributing factors
atomic_facts: Risk factors are described across child, family, and environmental levels.
Protective factors reduce likelihood of maltreatment and should be considered in context.
Observation of caregiver-child interactions can reveal escalating concern patterns.

subtopics.name: Objective recognition
atomic_facts: Staff should distinguish observed facts from assumptions.
Unexplained recurring injuries and extreme behavior changes warrant concern escalation.
Failure to act on credible indicators can place children at continued risk.

domains.name: Reporting Child Abuse and Neglect
domains.why_this_domain_exists: A distinct module covers legal duty to report, hotline channels, identity rules, and legal consequences for non-reporting.
domains.confidence_note: Overlap with D1 at the decision threshold; D2 owns steps after suspicion is formed.

policies: Every adult in Florida is required to report suspected abuse or neglect.
Approved channels include telephone, online report, fax, and relay/TTY access.
Reports should include objective observations and known facts.
definitions: Child care professionals are expected to provide identifying information when reporting.
Reports should be made immediately when suspicion is formed.
Personal investigation is not required before reporting suspicion.
procedures_workflows: Failure to report suspected abuse/neglect is identified as a criminal offense in source text.
Internal discussion does not replace formal hotline reporting.
Timely reporting supports child protection and legal compliance.
timeframes_thresholds: Reports should be made immediately when suspicion is formed.
roles_responsibilities: Every adult in Florida is required to report suspected abuse or neglect.
prohibited_actions_violations: Failure to report suspected abuse/neglect is identified as a criminal offense in source text.
scenario_judgment_calls: Child care professionals are expected to provide identifying information when reporting.
Reports should be made immediately when suspicion is formed.
Reports should include objective observations and known facts.
Timely reporting supports child protection and legal compliance.

subtopics.name: Legal obligations
atomic_facts: Every adult in Florida is required to report suspected abuse or neglect.
Child care professionals are expected to provide identifying information when reporting.
Failure to report suspected abuse/neglect is identified as a criminal offense in source text.

subtopics.name: Submission methods
atomic_facts: Approved channels include telephone, online report, fax, and relay/TTY access.
Reports should be made immediately when suspicion is formed.
Internal discussion does not replace formal hotline reporting.

subtopics.name: Reporting quality
atomic_facts: Reports should include objective observations and known facts.
Personal investigation is not required before reporting suspicion.
Timely reporting supports child protection and legal compliance.

domains.name: Observation and Screening
domains.why_this_domain_exists: Source modules explicitly separate observation/screening principles, methods, and early detection workflow from referral actions.
domains.confidence_note: Overlaps with D4 when observations lead to referrals; D3 remains evidence collection/interpretation.

policies: Observation and screening are ongoing and purposeful, not one-time events.
Checklists track presence or absence of target skills.
Patterns over time are more meaningful than isolated single events.
definitions: Each child should be viewed through individual traits and abilities.
Anecdotal records capture objective event notes shortly after occurrence.
Objective language should be used instead of labels or diagnoses.
procedures_workflows: Multi-method evidence strengthens reliability of developmental concerns.
Running records capture sequential behaviors in real time over a short period.
Observation data should guide supportive next steps.
timeframes_thresholds: Observation and screening are ongoing and purposeful, not one-time events.
scenario_judgment_calls: Each child should be viewed through individual traits and abilities.
Objective language should be used instead of labels or diagnoses.
Observation data should guide supportive next steps.

subtopics.name: Ongoing, purposeful process
atomic_facts: Observation and screening are ongoing and purposeful, not one-time events.
Each child should be viewed through individual traits and abilities.
Multi-method evidence strengthens reliability of developmental concerns.

subtopics.name: Checklist, anecdotal, running records
atomic_facts: Checklists track presence or absence of target skills.
Anecdotal records capture objective event notes shortly after occurrence.
Running records capture sequential behaviors in real time over a short period.

subtopics.name: Document then act
atomic_facts: Patterns over time are more meaningful than isolated single events.
Objective language should be used instead of labels or diagnoses.
Observation data should guide supportive next steps.

domains.name: Referral and Collaboration
domains.why_this_domain_exists: Module 4 content describes transition from concern to referral, family communication, and service coordination as a separate competency.
domains.confidence_note: Intersecting boundaries with D3 and D6 are expected; D4 owns referral workflow and collaborative decision points.

policies: Referral begins after need identification supported by observations and documentation.
Family conversations should be respectful, clear, and collaborative.
Programs coordinate with appropriate community resources.
definitions: Early referral is linked to improved outcomes.
Share specific observed behaviors rather than judgments.
Referral does not end at handoff; follow-up matters.
procedures_workflows: Referral directs child/family to qualified professional services for evaluation.
Document referral discussions and next steps.
Confidentiality and professionalism remain essential through the process.
roles_responsibilities: Referral directs child/family to qualified professional services for evaluation.
Family conversations should be respectful, clear, and collaborative.
Programs coordinate with appropriate community resources.
scenario_judgment_calls: Family conversations should be respectful, clear, and collaborative.
Referral does not end at handoff; follow-up matters.

subtopics.name: When to initiate referral
atomic_facts: Referral begins after need identification supported by observations and documentation.
Early referral is linked to improved outcomes.
Referral directs child/family to qualified professional services for evaluation.

subtopics.name: Supportive communication
atomic_facts: Family conversations should be respectful, clear, and collaborative.
Share specific observed behaviors rather than judgments.
Document referral discussions and next steps.

subtopics.name: Follow-through
atomic_facts: Programs coordinate with appropriate community resources.
Referral does not end at handoff; follow-up matters.
Confidentiality and professionalism remain essential through the process.

domains.name: Child Care Facility Rules and Regulatory Framework
domains.why_this_domain_exists: Module 5 content focuses on licensing structure, program classifications, inspections, capacity, and baseline compliance requirements.
domains.confidence_note: Overlap with D6 occurs because both involve compliance; D5 is framework and rule structure.

policies: Regulation exists to protect child health, safety, and well-being.
Licensure must be maintained with required application cycles.
Required records should be available for licensing review.
definitions: Source materials distinguish licensed, exempt, and specialized care contexts.
Inspections are used to verify compliance with standards.
Family and licensing access during operational hours is emphasized in summaries.
procedures_workflows: Statutes, code, and handbook guidance function together in compliance practice.
Enrollment records and ratios are core compliance evidence.
Noncompliance can trigger corrective and enforcement actions.
roles_responsibilities: Family and licensing access during operational hours is emphasized in summaries.
prohibited_actions_violations: Noncompliance can trigger corrective and enforcement actions.
scenario_judgment_calls: Required records should be available for licensing review.

subtopics.name: Why rules exist
atomic_facts: Regulation exists to protect child health, safety, and well-being.
Source materials distinguish licensed, exempt, and specialized care contexts.
Statutes, code, and handbook guidance function together in compliance practice.

subtopics.name: Operational compliance
atomic_facts: Licensure must be maintained with required application cycles.
Inspections are used to verify compliance with standards.
Enrollment records and ratios are core compliance evidence.

subtopics.name: Transparency obligations
atomic_facts: Required records should be available for licensing review.
Family and licensing access during operational hours is emphasized in summaries.
Noncompliance can trigger corrective and enforcement actions.

domains.name: Health, Safety, Training, and Professionalism
domains.why_this_domain_exists: Module 6 focuses on daily hazard control, staff training timelines, violation classes, sanctions, and professional development expectations.
domains.confidence_note: Some health-safety requirements connect to D5 facility rules; D6 focuses on day-to-day implementation and workforce competence.

policies: Daily indoor/outdoor checks are required safety practice.
New personnel must begin training within the 90-day window stated in source summaries.
Violations are categorized (Class I/II/III) with severity considerations.
definitions: Hazardous materials and firearms must remain inaccessible to children.
Forty-hour introductory training completion is a core requirement or approved equivalent path.
Sanctions depend on violated standard, frequency, and severity.
procedures_workflows: Capacity and usable space decisions affect daily safety planning.
Recurring training topics include literacy, fire extinguisher use, and additional annual topics named by source summaries.
Professional development plans support continuous improvement and compliance.
timeframes_thresholds: New personnel must begin training within the 90-day window stated in source summaries.
Forty-hour introductory training completion is a core requirement or approved equivalent path.
roles_responsibilities: New personnel must begin training within the 90-day window stated in source summaries.
prohibited_actions_violations: Hazardous materials and firearms must remain inaccessible to children.
Violations are categorized (Class I/II/III) with severity considerations.

subtopics.name: Hazard prevention
atomic_facts: Daily indoor/outdoor checks are required safety practice.
Hazardous materials and firearms must remain inaccessible to children.
Capacity and usable space decisions affect daily safety planning.

subtopics.name: Initial and ongoing training
atomic_facts: New personnel must begin training within the 90-day window stated in source summaries.
Forty-hour introductory training completion is a core requirement or approved equivalent path.
Recurring training topics include literacy, fire extinguisher use, and additional annual topics named by source summaries.

subtopics.name: Violations and growth
atomic_facts: Violations are categorized (Class I/II/III) with severity considerations.
Sanctions depend on violated standard, frequency, and severity.
Professional development plans support continuous improvement and compliance.
